awd_titl_txt: SHF: Small: From Declarative Specifications of Search Problems to Efficient Solutions
awd_abstract_narration:
Search is one of the fundamental techniques used by many intelligent software systems. There is a big chasm between the languages that programmers use to describe problems and the encodings that are suitable for solvers to conduct search. This research aims to narrow the gap by designing and implementing algorithms for translating declarative specifications of combinatorial problems into efficient encodings. The intellectual merits are novel frameworks and algorithms for translating planning specifications into sophisticated and efficient tabled logic programs, and cutting-edge algorithms for compiling high-level constraints into SAT (satisfiability) encodings. The project's broader significance and importance are its potential to produce long-lasting, significant economic, educational, and social impact because of the ubiquity of combinatorial problems, and the resulting theory and prototypes that will form the technology which enables future systems to obtain high-quality solutions to a variety of combinatorial problems. 

This research will focus on two types of combinatorial problems: AI planning and constraint satisfaction problems solved using SAT. Tabled logic programming has been shown to be a powerful and flexible modeling and solving language for planning problems. Nevertheless, it is an art, not a science, to develop efficient planning models in tabled logic programming. The algorithms designed by this research for translating planning specifications into efficient tabled logic programs will have the following capabilities: (1) convert factored representations of states into structural representations that exploit symmetries; (2) extract domain-dependent control knowledge, such as deterministic actions and partial orders; and (3) learn representation-specific heuristics. Global constraints are an important part of constraint programming. They not only allow easy modeling of many problems, but also enable use of powerful propagation algorithms. SAT encoding algorithms have been proposed for some of the global constraints. Nevertheless, there are no well-established algorithms for encoding global constraints into SAT; many other global constraints, such as graph constraints, have not received much attention despite their usefulness in practical applications. This research will produce algorithms for a comprehensive set of global constraints, and will develop a cutting-edge constraint-solving system based on these algorithms.

por.por_cntn:
SAT solvers' performance has drastically improved during the past two decades, thanks to the inventions of techniques from conflict-driven clause learning, backjumping, variable and value selection heuristics, to random restarts. In order to harness the power of SAT solvers, one needs to encode high-level constraints into propositional logic expressions that are digestible by SAT solvers. This project has developed several novel encoding algorithms and optimization techniques for translating various kinds of high-level constraints into SAT. The findings have been published in several papers, and the resulting implementations have been offered through the Picat system (picat-lang.org) to the communities.

This project has popularized log encoding for domain variables and arithmetic constraints by devising effective optimizations, including preprocessing, constant propagation, equivalence reasoning, and common subexpression elimination. Log encoding had been perceived to be unsuited for arithmetic constraints due to its hindrance to propagation. This project showed that log encoding is competitive with these optimizations.

The multi-agent pathfinding (MAPF) problem has attracted considerable attention because of its relation to practical applications. This project has proposed a constraint-based declarative model for MAPF, and an effective encoding of the constraints into SAT for different MAPF objectives, including minimizing makespan and minimizing the sum of costs. This project has also investigated a range of MAPF variants, including collision types and unexpected delays.

Many constraint satisfaction problems involve synthesizing subgraphs that satisfy certain properties, including reachability, cyclicity and acyclicity. This project compared several SAT encoding methods for the Hamiltonian Cycle Problem (HCP), and devised preprocessing techniques for HCP.  The study has surprisingly revealed that, with optimizations and preprocessing, the binary adder encoding significantly outperforms earlier encodings. This project has also identified efficient SAT encodings for synthesizing subgraphs that are strongly connected and subgraphs that are acyclic.

The research results have been incorporated into the Picat system and delivered to the communities. In addition to the evaluations done for the scientific papers, the system has been evaluated through solver competitions. In 2022, Picat won two gold medals in the XCSP competition and two silver medals in the MiniZinc Challenge. The research results have also enriched Picat as a powerful and flexible modeling and solving language for combinatorial problems. The Picat team won the first place in the 2020 and 2021 LP/CP programming contests.

This project has also had significant impact on education. Several students participated in the project and made contributions. Picat has been used by several universities, such as CUNY, Stony Brook University, UT Dallas, and MIT.
